SafetyInspectionBy: FRM Safety Training and Consulting llc

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE  SUMMARY



Chelan Fruit Cooperative's (hereafter referred to as CFC) accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices. CFC is a group of fruit processing and cold storage facilities.  The facility covered in this report is located in an unincorporated area of Douglas County, approximately 1 mile upstream from Beebe Bridge at Chelan Falls, Washington State.



It is the policy of CFC to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.  Chelan Fruit Cooperative complies with OSHA and WA State process safety management rules and regulations, WA state safety regulations, and IIAR standards for good work practices.  



The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to standards and local codes at the time of installation.  Piping and equipment are secured and protected, engine room doors are tight fitting and open outwards. Other safety systems used include:

* Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely

* Suction trap hi-level float

* High discharge pressure shut down

* Low suction pressure shut down

* High discharge temperature shut down

* Oil pressure failure shut down

* High amperes shut down

* Automatic timer to prevent short cycling via computer controls

* Oil filters plugged shut down

* 250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

* 150 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations



CFC refrigeration personnel do respond to ammonia releases and have received training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120 in addition to training specifically for ammonia, but are not classified as a formal ammonia response team.  An emergency plan has been developed covering notification to public safety agencies and the public.  An evacuation plan for the plant has also been developed and all employees have received training on this plan. The emergency response plan has been

provided to and reviewed with the local Chelan County Fire Department.



At CFC anhydrous ammonia is used on-site in a closed system as a refrigerant. Ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance (EHS) list. There is approximately 24,439 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the Beebe Plant. The largest interconnected system could potentially release all of this product.  Chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:

* Prevent unnecessary human exposure

* Reduce the threat to our personnel

* Reduce the threat to the community



The facility is bordered on the west side by McNeil Canyon Road with the Columbia River running adjacent.  On the east side a steep hillside runs the full length of the plant.  On the north and south, rolling hills create many obstacles for air movement.  Wind from the east would stay at a much higher elevation and allow any release of ammonia to rise and dissipate in the atmosphere.  Wind from the west would move any ammonia released up the steep hillside and into the atmosphere.  Winds from the north or south would move ammonia into the rolling hills and upward into the atmosphere.  There is little risk of ammonia entering the river.  However, if ammonia did reach the river it would be diluted and swept away quickly.  The level of the river is controlled by Wells Dam to the north, and Rocky Reach Dam to the south.  The quantity of water moving past the facility will never be low enough that any released ammonia would be detectable or a danger to the public or the environment.



CFC uses other hazardous substances on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.  



The CFC Beebe Plant has not sustained any accidents involving ammonia in the last five years. 



Training on ammonia safety and detailed mechanical integrity will be a major ongoing process at Chelan Fruit Cooperativ

e Beebe Plant.  Review and update of the emergency plan will be done annually.  Drills and emergency evacuation practices will be executed semi-annually.  Training will be required for all employees who work around the ammonia system, including forklift personnel.  



The reason for this re-submission prior to the 5-year anniversary date is due to several changes in management involved in the operation of the refrigeration system.  This re-submission and overall review of the RMP and PSM programs, allows management to be thoroughly aware of all procedures and policies and fully prepared to operate the system safely.
